awd_titl_txt: CRII: CPS: Emerging Markets and Myopic Decision-Making in Multi-Modal Transportation Systems: Modeling and Validation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to create high-fidelity models, validated with real-world data, of mixed-mode travel decisions and emerging mobility markets. A growing subset of travelers make decisions informed by apps that optimize (mixed-mode) routes based on user-defined preferences. Locally optimized solutions tend to cause inefficiencies that are exacerbated by risk-sensitivity (arising from endogenous and exogenous uncertainties) in travelers. Traditional rational, utility maximization models tend not to capture these effects, particularly in short-horizon decisions that leave little time for cogitation and points of reference play a primary role in choice. The project aims to (a) learn models of traveler decision-making that account for risk-sensitivity and (b) develop models of market structures (e.g., ride-sharing platforms) that capture traveler valuations of mobility modes. 

The proposed research extends rational models of travel decisions by leveraging prospect theory for capturing risk-sensitivity and bounded rationality for capturing information asymmetries and myopia. These concepts will be integrated into an inverse reinforcement learning framework for which we seek online algorithms in support of control/incentive design. Moreover, we will develop technical approaches to modeling mobility market structures that include new queuing game-theoretic models that capture risk-sensitivity. The proposed work will benefit from multi-modal transit data available via municipal and industry partners for testing and validation within a well-developed testbed.

This project will highlight areas where municipalities can adjust their management strategies to supplement the sharing economy in addressing the service gap in an equitable way. Through collaborations with the Seattle Department of Transportation and industry partners Swiftly and IDAX, there is potential to translate results to practice. Graduate and undergraduate students will be heavily involved in the project and will have ample opportunity to engage with the community through our municipal partners as well as be exposed to the jobs of tomorrow's smart cities.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we tackled problems in urban mobility by creating high-fidelity models, validated with real-world data, of mixed-mode travel decisions and emerging mobility markets. As cities expand, existing infrastructure is being stressed and a service gap between what is needed and available is forming. At the same time, Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) and Internet of Things (IoT) technologies have permeated the transportation system resulting in rich data streams, constant connectivity, and innovative markets. These technologies support real-time, on-the-move decision-making; thus, there is a tight coupling between the societal-scale CPS dynamics (SCPS) and economic exchanges. The transportation system is experiencing greater penetration of private entities which see value in closing the service gap. In addition, a growing subset of travelers make decisions informed by apps that optimize mixed-mode routes based on user-defined preferences. Locally optimized solutions tend to cause inefficiencies which are exacerbated by the fact that risk-sensitive travelers face uncertainty. Traditional rational, utility maximization models tend not to capture these effects, particularly in decisions where there is limited time to cogitate and reference points (e.g., recent scenario experienced by the traveler) and risk play a significant role in the choice. Stochastic models that capture SCPS dynamics and traveler decision-making behaviors are needed to support effective interventions such as physical control or economic mechanisms.

With these motivations in mind, the overarching goal of this project was to develop a unified framework for assessing and addressing challenges emerging due to the evolution of the transportation system into a SCPS. Towards this end, we addressed the following aims:

  • (Aim 1) learn models of traveler decision-making that account for risk-sensitivity and myopia; 
  • (Aim 2) develop models of emerging market structures that capture traveler valuations of mobility modes.
  • ( Aim 3 ) validate models and algorithms developed as part of  Aim 1  and  Aim 2  using real-world data 

Insight into the interplay between modes enables more effective operations as well as supports mechanism design to mitigate inefficiencies. This project also benefited from multi-modal transit data available via municipal and industry partners for testing and validation within a well-developed testbed.

Over the course of the project, we addressed each of the aims and the work has been published in top conference venues and journals in control theory, machine learning, and artificial intelligence.

Regarding Aim 1, this project developed algorithms with performance guarantees on convergence to optimal solutions for learning models of human decision-making in SCPS that capture salient features of their decision-making process such as the effects of risk on decisions; as a result, our approach also has lead to highly interpretable and usable outcomes. For instance, understanding the role of risk on a users decision regarding transit options can aid policy makers in the design of policy for transportation infrastructure that provides wider accessibility by taking into account variations in, e.g, risk assessment across popultions of users. Risk in this context might pertain to reliability, trustworthiness, or even saftey.

Regarding Aim 2, this project developed new approaches for modeling the various platform supported, emerging market structures in the mobility space. Our focus was two-fold: (a) study and design of adaptive incentive architectures within existing non-traditional mobility markets such as two-sided ride/bike-sharing platforms and (b) understand the effects of uncertainty on efficiency in resource constrained environments with the longer term goal of leveraging these effects in the design of markets, mechanisms, and networks. Towards this end, we developed novel adaptive incentive mechanisms for shaping mutliple strategic users behavior both at the level of finite numbers of agents as well as at the aggregate or population level. Additionally, we developed a novel decision-dependent framework for learning mechanisms which takes into consideration the reaction of the population of agents at the time of design. The work in this aim also supported Aim 1: this project drew on behavioral economics in order to construct engineering solutions considerate of socio-economic factors. 

Regarding Aim 3, this project conducted a number of experiments from groundtruth data collection, human-machine interaction experiments on crowdsourcing platforms, and semi-synthetic experiments and simualtions based on large data sets, all in support of validating the outcomes of Aims 1 and 2. 

The outcomes of this project directly contributed to the fundamental science of CPS and smart and connected communities by creating a theoretical and computational framework for SCPS accounting for humans in the loop at scale. A diverse set of tools from machine learning, control theory, econometrics, game theory, and optimization were leveraged, and as a result the project made contributions not just in each of these areas but also to new interdisciplinary areas at their intersection. The results were also transitioned to practice via collaborations with municipalities such as Seattle, and industry partners IDAX data solutions. New courses on game theory and intelligent infrastructure were also developed, and undergraduate research was a key component of this project. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/11/2021
Modified by: Lillian Ratliff
por.por_txt_cntn:
In this project, we tackled problems in urban mobility by creating high-fidelity models, validated with real-world data, of mixed-mode travel decisions and emerging  mobility markets. As cities expand, existing infrastructure is being  stressed and a service gap between what is needed and available is  forming. At the same time, Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) and Internet of  Things (IoT) technologies have permeated the transportation system  resulting in rich data streams, constant connectivity, and innovative  markets. These technologies support real-time, on-the-move  decision-making; thus, there is a tight coupling between the  societal-scale CPS dynamics (SCPS) and economic exchanges. The  transportation system is experiencing greater penetration of private  entities which see value in closing the service gap. In addition, a  growing subset of travelers make decisions informed by apps that  optimize mixed-mode routes based on user-defined preferences. Locally  optimized solutions tend to cause inefficiencies which are exacerbated  by the fact that risk-sensitive travelers face uncertainty. Traditional  rational, utility maximization models tend not to capture these effects,  particularly in decisions where there is limited time to cogitate and  reference points (e.g., recent scenario experienced by the traveler) and  risk play a significant role in the choice. Stochastic models that  capture SCPS dynamics and traveler decision-making behaviors are needed  to support effective interventions such as physical control or economic  mechanisms.

With these motivations in mind, the overarching goal of this project was to develop a unified  framework for assessing and addressing challenges emerging due to the  evolution of the transportation system into a SCPS. Towards this end, we  addressed the following aims:

(Aim 1) learn models of traveler decision-making that account for risk-sensitivity and myopia; 
(Aim 2) develop models of emerging market structures that capture traveler valuations of mobility modes.
( Aim 3 ) validate models and algorithms developed as part of  Aim 1  and  Aim 2  using real-world data 


Insight into the interplay between modes enables more effective  operations as well as supports mechanism design to mitigate  inefficiencies. This project also benefited from multi-modal  transit data available via municipal and industry partners for testing  and validation within a well-developed testbed.

Over the course of the project, we addressed each of the aims and the work has been published in top conference venues and journals in control theory, machine learning, and artificial intelligence.

Regarding Aim 1, this project developed algorithms with performance guarantees on convergence to optimal solutions for learning models of  human decision-making in SCPS that capture salient features of their  decision-making process such as the effects of risk on decisions; as a result, our approach also has lead to highly interpretable and usable outcomes. For instance, understanding the role of risk on a users decision regarding transit options can aid policy makers in the design of policy for transportation infrastructure that provides wider accessibility by taking into account variations in, e.g, risk assessment across popultions of users. Risk in this context might pertain to reliability, trustworthiness, or even saftey.

Regarding Aim 2, this project developed new approaches for modeling the various platform supported,  emerging market structures in the mobility space. Our focus was two-fold: (a) study and design of adaptive incentive  architectures within existing non-traditional mobility markets such as  two-sided ride/bike-sharing platforms and (b) understand the effects of  uncertainty on efficiency in resource constrained environments with the  longer term goal of leveraging these effects in the design of markets,  mechanisms, and networks. Towards this end, we developed novel adaptive incentive mechanisms for shaping mutliple strategic users behavior both at the level of finite numbers of agents as well as at the aggregate or population level. Additionally, we developed a novel decision-dependent framework for learning mechanisms which takes into consideration the reaction of the population of agents at the time of design. The work in this aim also supported Aim 1: this project drew on behavioral economics in order to construct engineering solutions considerate of socio-economic factors. 

Regarding Aim 3, this project conducted a number of experiments from groundtruth data collection, human-machine interaction experiments on crowdsourcing platforms, and semi-synthetic experiments and simualtions based on large data sets, all in support of validating the outcomes of Aims 1 and 2. 


The outcomes of this project directly contributed to  the fundamental science of CPS and smart and connected  communities by creating a theoretical and computational framework for  SCPS accounting for humans in the loop at scale. A diverse set of tools from machine learning, control theory, econometrics, game theory, and optimization were leveraged, and as a result the project made contributions not just in each of these areas but also to new interdisciplinary areas at their intersection. The results were also transitioned to practice via collaborations with municipalities such as Seattle, and industry partners IDAX data solutions. New courses on game theory and intelligent infrastructure were also developed, and undergraduate research was a key component of this project.
